title: Thursday, 21st June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Hi. Good morning. Hello there. Welcome. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily markets live thing.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
wayneJ Morning
Manxish Morning each
BE11:05am

No Treasury Select Committee to provide material today.

Soundbuy Morning.
BE11:06am

Did you watch yesterday afternoon? Kinda fun, wasn't it?

11:05 am
BE11:06am

https://ftalphavil...live/2018-06-20-2/

Soundbuy Did Smurfit get a mention? I was engaged elsewhere........
Pharma Curious that there were no hodlers in evidence on the right. Wonder if they have given up.

Iz did an amazing job of holding her temper while three crypto industry types spoke absolute bobbins.

BE11:08am

Questions were of ...... variable ........ quality. But I think most of the panel got the gist in the end.

Manxish The assertion that people come to Blockchain 'to live' was my highlight
11:09 am

Anyway, how long is it since we linked to Michael Fowke?

vonB Morning
BE11:10am

He did crypto yesterday too, coincidentally: http://moneyisthew...twenty-crypto.html

Peace and Love Yesterday's market Live afternoon extra helping was as fun as informative
BE11:11am

And I'm genuinely delighted to see hit blog still ticking. It's a decade-long surrealist art project that probably deserves to win the Turner.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

http://moneyistheway.blogspot.com/

undefined
vonB Anything on Daimler and tariff wars?
BE11:12am

We, however, need to find something to talk about in this damn market.

wayneJ Second Daimler
cheeckychappy How about Glencore Bunge?
wayneJ And Trade Wars
11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@cheeckychappy: sigh.)

BE11:13am

FTSE's flat.

cheeckychappy @BE - you started it this time round...
wayneJ And is there a Dixons capital markets day today
BE11:13am

Ex divs and not a lot of news.

FJ German gas guzzlers sputtering...German economy coming to a grinding unexpected halt.
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Daimler, of all things, requested post the profit warning overnight.

BE11:14am

Mercedes, Vans and Busses all get guidance cut.

wayneJ And the latest turns and twist in Disney / Comcast / Fox / Sky / Murdochs etc....
BE11:15am

EBIT is now expected to be slightly below the prior year level at Mercedes-Benz Cars (previously slightly above), significantly below the prior year level at Mercedes-Benz Vans (previously slightly below) and in the magnitude of the prior year level at Daimler Buses (previously slightly above). For the group as a whole EBIT is now forecast to be slightly below the previous year's level (previously slightly above).

wayneJ And May questioning why the UK considers itself a Tier One World Power - and the consequence shrinking of the Royal Navy from its 19 ships to.....
11:15 am
BE11:16am

That's Barclays' summary, which notes trade wars but also diesel regulation and Brazil problems.

BE11:16am

Daimler is facing a perfect storm, being hit by multiples headwinds simultaneously

BE11:16am

1) Following China’s decision in May to lower tariffs on car imports from 25-15%, tariffs specifically on US imports are now to be raised to 40%. Mercedes will struggle to pass this cost on to Chinese buyers of the GLE and GLS models that it imports into China from the US, particularly as some competitors import vehicles from Europe and will therefore continue to benefit from the initial reduction in tariffs to 15%. A significantly negative volume and price effect is likely to be the result.

wayneJ Or will the Brexit dividend extend to cover the armed forces - how else is the ratio of Captains to ships or Generals to infantry going to change?
11:16 am
BE11:16am

2) [...] all European OEMs must get their vehicles accredited under the new testing cycle by September 1st. Daimler had seemed in good shape on this front. Yet from speaking to IR we understand that additional testing demand in connection with Daimler’s most recent diesel recall has now led to a shortage of both internal and external testing capacity and may mean the WLTP deadline cannot be met. This dynamic explains both some of the adjustment to the Mercedes guidance and the lowered forecasts for Vans.

BE11:16am

3) Finally, strikes in Brazil are set to burden demand in Latin America for Daimler buses.

These headwinds come on top of two other issues burdening Q2 a fire at a magnesium supplier in the US, which temporarily halted US production, and Mercedes cutting Chinese prices within two days of May’s initial announcement that import tariffs would be lowered in July (thus effectively subsiding sales).

Maverick Well the big news in the City has surely got to be Valbury, difficult to see the FCA allowing them to keep their licence....
sprout Daimler consensus P/E now below its divi yield... although I suspect estimates for both have a way to come down.
BE11:17am

In terms of the sector readthrough, BMW's the obvious one.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

c.13% of units and 14% of profits at risk, says Merrill.

Tom Dalgleish Brazil copping a caning lately
wayneJ Aren't US SUV import taxes tied up with agriculture via the Chicken tax so very hard for the US to lower tariffs (some are proposing EU/ US zero tariffs on autos)
BE11:18am

That's to import tariffs, I mean. Peugeot relatively safest with 80% unit exposure to Europe

estrangedcapitalist Morning boys
wayneJ BMW X3 production in South Carolina but BMW is ramping an X3 factory in China
Pharma Not sure being 80% exposed to Europe is a strength.
alewis2005 afternoon markets live was v entertaining, thanks
BE11:19am

Though Kepler's not entirely believing Daimler's talk that it's all sector.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Revised guidance now implies reported EBIT in the range of EUR13.9-
14.4bn. In view of the fallout from the US-China trade war, we fully
understand that the fresh increase in import duties in China for US-built
vehicles impacts unit sales of its GLE, GLE coupé, and GLS models, which we estimate may cost Daimler some EUR200-400m (BMW is similarly exposed with its X4, X5 and X6 models, but VW is not, as it does not export from the US to China). However, we are somewhat surprised about the fact that WLPT/RDE Europe impacts earnings to a greater extent than thought (Daimler has indicated for several months that it will be a burden though), which may be a hint that problems related to this are more serious than thought. In the absence of any further information, we were also surprised that the recall triggered such a negative swing in the Van division’s guidance.

Je Suis Muppet @estrangedcap ... u only say hello to boys ?
Je Suis Muppet ;O)
Tom Dalgleish More proof that tariffs are a war on workers
BE11:21am

Morgan Stanley's more trusting.

BE11:21am

We do not believe Daimler will be the only OEM to reduce guidance. Other
OEMs are also exposed to similar trends that Daimler cites in various degrees. Clearly, BMW’s SUV exports from the US may suffer similarly to Daimler. WLTP will affect all OEMs in Europe in 2H 2018.
Conclusion- Daimler was already cheap. Now consensus EPS will come down. We think it likely stays cheap for now. It is tough to see how the shares rerate until EPS stabilises. Remains EW.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Okay, bored of cars now.

undefined
pancakes or waffles @JSM #woke
Pharma US car import tariffs - 2.5%EU car import tariffs - 10%In a sane world the EU tariffs would fall...
wayneJ @Pharma is there a different rate for SUVs
Div Second Glencore/Bunge
wayneJ @Pharma - see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicken_tax
wayneJ @BE - do u have a car?
mosschops Isn't Peugeot heavily exposed to Iran? Something like 10% of sales there.
BE11:24am

@ROTR, there's nothing to say on Bunge/Glencore.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

People have in recent days been very, very keen to see Bunge rumours reported in the press.

Pharma @wayneJ don't know. In the US SUVs are often lumped in with light trucks, but they view both as a form of regular personal transportation.
BE11:25am

They got their wish yesterday in the Telegraph: https://www.telegr...bunge-bid-rumours/

BE11:26am

But -- how do I put this politely? -- I doubt their first choice of outlet was the Telegraph.

cracklenpop Netflix is the investment story of the year so far, share price has doubled in that time, closed at another new high last night
cheeckychappy @BE - Meow!
11:27 am
BE11:27am

I think it's fair to suggest that every other news organisation that tends to chase M&A rumours has heard similar rumours regarding Bunge in recent days and weeks, but none has grown comfortable enough to put them in print.

Tom Dalgleish NFLX incredible. Nobody else can stream stuff?
Tom Dalgleish BE, so what is the purpose of a baseless rumour?
BE11:29am

The most recent idea getting put around, incidentally, was that Glencore had hired a UK bank I won't name to work on an offer. We've found no reason yet to think that's accurate so haven't reported it.

Tom Dalgleish To dump I suppose
BE11:29am

The end.

11:29 am
undefined
BE11:30am

(@Tom: it's not my place to speculate even hypothetically on the motivations on stale bulls wishing to exit positions.)

wayneJ @Pharma - if a vehicle has a GVWR of over 6,000lbs and a capability for a flat load area of at least 6 ft in length then it is counted as a light truck - hence a lot of SUVs have seats that can be made flat to create the load area
BE11:31am

Okay, what else?

rw42 Pretty massive bandwidth & storage requirements to stream video at scale - surprised youtube doesn't take a look though!
BW6 @BE anything on Ferrexpo (FXPO)?
11:31 am
BE11:31am

There's Shire, which is being reported by the wires this morning to be up on Cinryze approval. Though of course that's irrelevant.

Soundbuy Liked the 'trainee' day trader in France using the 'real' not demo platform story............
BE11:32am

Market doesn't really give a stuff about paediatric hereditary angioedema. It gives a stuff about Takeda, which was up nearly 5% overnight.

BE11:33am

That move, I think, is on UBS saying investors need to chill.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

We have drawn up a scenario analysis for after the integration of Shire, we updated our model and created a merger model, and we lift our PT to ¥6,700 and upgrade our rating to Buy from Neutral. We believe new stock issuance is likely to be approved at the extraordinary shareholders' meeting at the end of 2018. In our view, the proposal to acquire Shire is not strategic but opportunistic and the cash flow that could be obtained should be appealing to investors.

Pharma @wayneJ another reason that trade rules, excepting those on safety/health, are stupid.
BE11:34am

Many investors seem to be concerned about the proposed acquisition because of 1) the possibility of a decline in reported (GAAP) EPS; 2) growth in borrowings of ¥3trn or more; 3) the merger process itself; 4) maintenance of the dividend; 5) supply-demand including flow-back; and 6) the perceived lack of a ‘strategic fit.’ In our view, Core EPS is a good indicator of a company's cash generation capabilities: we estimate that Takeda's Core EPS could rise 45% in FY19 relative to its pre-merger level and we think the dividend could be increased around FY20. If Takeda does not acquire Shire, the dividend will probably be unchanged for some time.

undefined
11:34 am
BE11:35am

@Soundbuy, thanks for the reminder. Strange story!

BE11:35am

A trainee day trader in France is suing a British brokerage for an amount comparable to almost its entire annual revenue after it seized the €10m profit he made using what he initially thought was a demonstration version of its platform.

BE11:35am

.... okay ......

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Harouna Traoré opened a €20,000 account at Valbury Capital, a UK-based brokerage, last summer after using a dummy version of its platform to learn how to trade equity futures as a retail investor on a trading course in Paris.

A couple of weeks later, he was practising trading at home on what he believed to be the demo version — placing €1bn of orders for European and US equity futures — before realising that it was the live platform and he had run up a loss of more than €1m.

BE11:35am

.................. uh?

BE11:36am

He continued trading, eventually building up a $5bn position in US equity futures and turning the loss into a profit of more than €10m.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

What!?

11:38 am

How does one even put on a $5bn position

Flaneur IslandDweller - indeed. I did it once on live TV. Luckily no one noticed.
IslandDweller Hornblower - the Merc models exported are fairly niche models - cheaper to only have one production line for everywhere than split production
tonyb 5bn: surreal and impossiblemaybe in demo mode
alewis2005 even at 100x leverage you'll need 50m

And the narrative -- he lost a lot of money so he doubled down to bet an incredibly large amount of money and won big -- is ...... well, it's every gambler's fantasy isn't it?

Tom Dalgleish Alewis & Island, so the customer is always wrong?
IslandDweller Not understanding the question Tom?
BT My favourite bit is how (reading between the lines) he ended up a million in the hole due to bad controls, emailed to complain that he thought he was still on a practice account, then made 11m back and now wants them to pay out...
bones30 One of my theories about some of these techs e.g. twtr is that profits previously illusive because of technical debt. Once this is dealt with though. I'm not sure people understand the nature of technical debt well.
tonyb gearing is 100:1 at topps - how does 20k make you 10m?
BE11:41am

And betting $5bn on a $20k deposit is ......... well, shouldn't the FCA be the ones paying attention here? If it's true? Which I guess it might be? Not wishing to prejudge anything.

Tom Dalgleish Island, was it your mistake?
littleclenches this story is utterly implausiblle
11:41 am
undefined
littleclenches slow news day
rw42 It would be amusing if it was as simple as he phoned up and asked them to put some fake money on his demo account, giving his live account ID and no one at the broker bothered to check..
tonyb the end of valbury in any case...
BE11:42am

Okay, what else can we use to fill our precious time together?

IslandDweller Tom - not mine - another member of my team - but we discovered the error as soon as Exchange opened and stopped it. Many procedures reviewed and tightened in consequence

There's Dixons, but by god it's dull.

11:42 am
Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 196.35, up 5.6 (+2.94%), High: 199.75, Low: 193.50, Volume: 2.36m
BE11:43am

Numbers match the profit warning, guidance doesn't change, strategy update is nothing really.

wayneJ Any views on May and UK defence - or is that frothing mouths at the Telegraph and Daily Fail?
BE11:43am

Shares are cheap but that's no reason to buy them.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Who can summarise for us? Citi? Citi can.

alewis2005 btw anyone at a loose end, if you come along to my gfs show I'll buy you a drink: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/tasteofshakespeare/134643/Starts tonight - Thurs/Fri this and next week.
BE11:44am

Given the early trading statement, there is very little surprising in DC's FY results. Headline PBT (£382m), dividend (11.25p) and net debt (£249m) are all in line with previous guidance. At £172m, FCF is down -3% yoy. At the results meetings we would expect further detail on profit split and trajectory of UK electricals and mobile businesses.

Tom Dalgleish I still can’t see why Best Buy is booming but Dixons can’t win a trick but then being neither Brit nor American maybe I’m missing something
bones30 Interesting about openbsd and hyperthreading yesterday. Anyone follow? https://www.theregister.co.uk/AMP/2018/06/20/openbsd_disables_intels_hyperthreading/
BE11:44am

FY18 Group Headline PBT £382m, EPS 26.2p –21.8% yoy (Citi £382m) — In line with guidance, Group EBIT was £400m (Citi £400m). Splitting EBIT by region: UK&Ireland £281m (Citi £273m), Nordics £101m (Citi £110m) and Greece £18m (Citi £17m). Including interest of -£18m (Citi-£18m) drove Headline PBT of £382m, - 22% yoy. FY DPS 11.25p, flat yoy as previously announced.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Net debt £249m (Citi £256m) — In-line with previous guidance and included Capex of £173m and restructuring costs of £47m. Total free cash flow was £172m, down - 3% yoy despite the -20% drop in headline PBT.
 4Q trends already reported — DC has already reported 4Q LFL revenue trends: +1% for UK&I (Elec +1%, mob flat), +8% for Nordics and +10% for Greece.
 Implications — April FY19 PBT retained — We forecast FY19e PBT £300m, EPS 20.3p, -21.5% yoy. This assumes UK&I sales -4.1% (inc LFL -2.2%), Nordic LFL sales of +2% and Greece LFL +2%. Our overall EBIT is £318m. Our EPS of 32.3p assumes a tax rate of 22%.
 Buy rating, TP 220p — Our target price of 220p is based on a FY19e SOTP valuation. The UK electricals business is valued at 9x EV/EBIT, in line with the sector average. At this value, we estimate the FCF yield at c.6.0%, in line with lowgrowth sustainable yields in the sector. The European businesses are valued at 9x EV/EBIT while CPW is valued at zero. At this level, the stock would trade on EV/EBIT of 10.5x, PE of 10.9x and a dividend yield of 6.2% for FY19e.

BE11:45am

And RBC.

BE11:45am

We have an Outperform rating as we see potential valuation upside in DC on recovered earnings, but we recognise this will take time to realise, given short-term pressure on margins, as the £ has weakened again versus the USD and as earnings visibility is less than some other companies in the sector.
Valuation is undemanding with a CY18E P/E of c.7.3x and a 5.9% dividend yield, albeit with a lower level of earnings visibility and transparency than some other companies in the sector.

alewis2005 and in other news, the startup I work for is officially 'hot'! http://www.cityam.com/287910/these-50-hottest-fintech-startups-europe-right-now-london

As Excel notes, we're nine minutes away from the BOE so may as well hang on for that.

Tom Dalgleish Pancake........we’re talking about blowouts
Waterloo Could list all the trade retaliations already announced
BE11:53am

Here's Reid at DB to provide a neat wee summary.

BE11:53am

Ahead of today’s BOE meeting, our economists note that the focus will be
squarely on the minutes and in particular the tone and language used to assess last week's mostly dismal data. In particular, the drop in wage growth (mom) for the first time in over a year and the sharp fall in industrial production should be a topic of discussion. On the one hand, poor output data to kick off Q2 could raise some concerns for the MPC regarding the strength of UK economy. On the other, stronger retail sales data may keep hawks optimistic of a bounce back in Q2. They go on to say that while it is still early days, the BoE could strike a less hawkish tone though the team expect them to largely look past this in anticipation of May data (the last data they will see before the August MPC meeting). In summary our economists expect no change in policy today but still think August is ‘live’ for an opportunistic rate hike (currently priced at a little over 25% probability for a hike).

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We've also got Carney's Mansion House speech tonight, meaning it's best to avoid Bank Station on your route home.

Tom Dalgleish Wayne, Micron is chips and Siltronic is fab
Twiggy CO2 shortage?
BE11:55am

You'd expect him to stick to the "sound cautious but stay hawkish" script.

Excel Developer BofE 7-2 last month.
wayneJ Siltronic is 300mm wafers - biggest customers are memory co.s - and virtually all the customers are outside China
BE11:56am

Citi also, since we're here.

wayneJ @Tom D - also continued shortages of those there wafers
11:56 am
BE11:56am

The overwhelming consensus is that the MPC will not budge today. No one in the Bloomberg consensus (61 estimates) expects a hike and the market is priced with just a 2% chance (16:30 BST 20Jun18). We agree with no change, but believe there is more chance than implied. The data has been mixed, but generally supports the idea that Q1 weakness was erratic. Several MPC members seem keen to get on with a hike. In that context, there may be a hawkish nod today towards a hike in August, perhaps via a 6-3 vote (vs 7-2 last). Market pricing for August has dipped to a 47% chance (16:30 BST 20Jun18). That seems too low to us, setting up the possibility of a bearish reaction today. Carney’s speech at Mansion House this evening offers a further opportunity to guide expectations, especially in the absence of a press conference at this non-Inflation Report meeting

undefined
Tom Dalgleish So China fabbing now?
BE11:57am

......................And yet, we still have four minutes to fill.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

How about this note from HSBC on mining cycles? That'll do it.

wayneJ China is trying to build fabs to reduce its silicon deficit. Issues include IP and supply of equipment / wafers. Realistically China will get to some volumes in 2020 but still a long time to catch up
Excel Developer Dollar Index DXY at a ~8 month high.
Shinshin @BE Ascot tips ?
BE11:59am

BT Back to the Valbury story - surely they're just doing the standard thing of taking 1%, not hedging in the markets, and relying on punters getting carried out? That's why there was no margin calls from brokers or any necessarily any cash-calls - they've just had rubbish systems where the limits have malfunctioned for some reason have malfunctioned and let him build up huge losses then huge gains
wayneJ @Tom D - don't laugh but at least one Chinese memory co has been found to be using Intel photos on its web page to allegedly show its 'progress'
BE11:59am

We're usually a bit snide about those kind of graphs, but that one's good.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

1. Look at all the money. The start of the super-cycle saw rising commodity prices drive revenue growth faster than costs leading to strong cash generation.

BE12:00pm

 2. Spend all the money. Industry believed demand growth in China would continue indefinitely at a frenetic pace and invested heavily in volume growth and M&A as a result.
 3. Give us all the money. Shareholders started demanding increased cash returns, seeing the cycle beginning to waiver.
 4. There is no money. 2009 saw a dramatic collapse in commodity prices coinciding with the GFC. A subsequent recovery from 2010-2014 and second collapse in 2015 then occurred.

Excel Developer Bank of England MPC 6-3 !!!!
bones30 Wayne. Imagine that.
BE12:00pm

 5. Fix the fallout. Post 2015 the mining industry aggressively restructured balance sheets, cut capex, reduced costs and began to manage supply as financial concerns grew given elevated debt levels.
 6. Atone for sins of the past. As balance sheets recovered and commodity prices rose from mid-2016, a new crop of CEOs began to prioritise cash returns to shareholders, largely shunning M&A and mega-projects.
 7. How long can it last? The industry is already sowing the seeds of the next mining cycle, in our view. Although we find ourselves in an environment of lower commodities demand, the lack of investment and reluctance to allocate capital away from shareholder returns is likely to have already sown the seeds of a future cycle. While the current crop of CEOs remain in place we are unlikely to see these priorities change but new incumbents may think differently.

alewis2005 @Excel sounds like a possible world cup score
12:00 pm
undefined
BE12:01pm

Okay, here we are. Unchanged, 6-3.

wayneJ And another with alleged native Chinese memory production turned out to be buying memory wafers from a Korean co and just sliced / dicing and testing.....

And won't consider reducing QE debt until rates hit 1.5%.

wayneJ Hence worth being wary of some analysts 'gloom and doom' forecasts of pending massive Chinese supply coming

And that, I think, will do for Thursday.

cracklenpop @ Shinshin Vintage Brut in the Norfolk

Ta for joining. Back tomorrow, you'd assume.
